node.title: Tom Hardy's loveable monster returns in a scrappy sequel smart enough to play totally dumb
node.alt: Man with scruffy dark hair and stubble wears white shirt and dark jacket outside prison cell in which a blonde man sits cuffed.
node.description: The first Venom was panned, but Andy Serkis’s sequel is unapologetically juvenile - with comedic banter, gross-out effects and epic CGI clashes. It’s also surprisingly tender.
node.content:
["Although it was despised by critics who wouldn't know a good time if it arrived from a distant galaxy and took possession of their bodies, the first Venom (2018) was enjoyably rowdy trash \u2013 a comic book movie that felt like a throwback to a time before Christopher Nolan and the Marvel Cinematic Universe and the whole genre taking itself so goddamn seriously.", "It was chaotic and more than a little crude, even if the demonic alien symbiote that attached itself to star Tom Hardy turned out to have a big old soft side.", "In the spirit of its predecessor, Venom: Let There Be Carnage is a sequel in the old style: less inspired and essentially more of the same \u2013 and largely indifferent to the demands of the contemporary superhero model. (At least until the inevitable post-credits moment that makes the whole thing seem suspiciously like an excuse to bring the characters into a wider franchise.)", "", "
Tom Hardy, pictured,\u00a0has a \"story by\" credit on the film \u2014 alongside British screenwriter Kelly Marcel \u2014\u00a0and is also a producer.(Supplied: Sony)
", "You'll recall from the previous film that interstellar castaway Venom \u2014\u00a0the loveable shapeshifting slime who looks like a cross between a luchador, a killer whale and HR Giger's alien \u2014\u00a0had taken possession of Hardy's down-on-his-luck investigative journalist Eddie Brock, establishing a sort of wobbly co-occupancy born of mutual need.", "\"You live in my body, you live by my rules,\" Eddie warns his unpredictable guest, whose frustration at his host's human limitations \u2014\u00a0both physical and ethical \u2014\u00a0continues to be a source of amusing, slapstick comedy.", "This odd couple have settled into a more-or-less covert existence, with the carnivorous Venom promising not to eat people and Eddie feeding him a diet of chocolate and chickens \u2014\u00a0a menu that Venom has, understandably, grown to resent.", "But that's about to be the least of their problems when larger-than-life serial killer Cletus Kasady \u2014 Woody Harrelson, teased at the tail of the first film \u2014\u00a0sends Eddie an invite to interview him at the prison where he's awaiting execution. Turns out Eddie helped put him there, and Cletus is determined to make the reporter pay.", "", "
Serkis told Screenrant: \"It was a golden opportunity to play in an environment where you've got these marginal, dysfunctional, screwed-up characters.\"(Supplied: Sony)
", "Cletus takes a bite out of Eddie's \u2014 and Venom's \u2014\u00a0flesh, transforming into his own diabolical alien symbiote, Carnage, a tentacled, crimson monster who breaks out of prison and duly sets about laying waste to the city.", "In return for hosting his reign of terror, Carnage agrees to help Cletus rescue his old girlfriend, Frances Barrison (Naomie Harris) \u2014\u00a0aka sound-manipulating villain Shriek \u2014\u00a0from the asylum where she's languished since the mid-90s.", "He seems to unleash a Woody Harrelson performance from the era, too, complete with ridiculous wig, Vegas dirtbag attire, and a stolen cherry-red Mustang convertible in which Cletus and Frances tear through the streets of San Francisco.", "It's a comically minimal plot, one that barely pushes the film over its breezy 97-minute running time\u00a0but, once again, Hardy \u2014\u00a0who voices Venom as a deranged-but-needy alter ego \u2014\u00a0proves there's considerable fun to be had with this dual personality\u00a0premise, and even a touch of soul.", "", "
\"The\u00a0main objective [is]: can I land Eddie Brock and Venom as an established Marvel superhero?\" Hardy told Esquire of the first Venom film.(Supplied: Sony)
", "The comedy is less surprising than it was in the first film, where the gruff, disagreeable Venom wrestled with Eddie's reporter like a comic-book Lily Tomlin and Steve Martin in All of Me (1984) mixed with Vincent D'Onofrio's indelible performance in Men in Black (1997).", "There's nothing here as funny as the moment in the previous film when a sweaty, paranoid Eddie cut loose in a fancy seafood restaurant to munch on live lobsters at Venom's behest.", "Instead, the body-occupancy war has given way to the amusing, sometimes tender bickering of an old married couple, where the film seems less concerned with a duel between the Id and the Ego than the trials of domestic partnership \u2014\u00a0or just learning to love the many sides of yourself.", "In one scene, Venom, on the loose from Eddie's body, crashes a Halloween costume party at a dance club, where \u2014\u00a0wearing glowstick hula hoops like floral leis \u2014\u00a0he hijacks the stage mic and delivers a blustery, though no-less-heartfelt \"coming out\"\u00a0speech.", "\"I am out of the Eddie closet,\" he tearfully declares, to the approving \u2014\u00a0if somewhat bewildered \u2014\u00a0cheers of the club's assembled throng, who may as well be stand-ins for the online fandom that \"shipped\"\u00a0Venom and Eddie in the wake of the first film. (At one point, the sequel was even going to be called Venom: Love Will Tear Us Apart.)", "It's this kind of comedy that gives the movie, like the first, its personality, where scenes that appear designed as throwaway gags are afforded as much weight as the ostensible \u2014\u00a0and always less-interesting \u2014\u00a0business of furthering the overall plot.", "", "
\"[Eddie and Venom] have very different ideas about the world and are rubbing against each other in a very small apartment,\" Hardy told The AV Club.(Supplied: Sony)
", "Director Andy Serkis, stepping in for Ruben Fleischer, knows a thing or two about orchestrating computer-generated action: The actor and motion-capture titan behind everything from Gollum to the Planet of the Apes reboots brings his eye for movement to the action, lending the warring symbiotes a buoyant mix of flesh and fantasy.", "Cinematographer Robert Richardson (Once Upon a Time in Hollywood; Natural Born Killers), meanwhile, captures the city with moody, pulpy relish.", "Serkis and Richardson give the film's climactic showdown atop an expressionist-lit church a gothic, Burton-Batman vibe, another reminder that this is a movie that could have come out in 1997 \u2014\u00a0when Venom co-creator Todd McFarlane's Spawn terrorised cinemas with its unholy rocktronica soundtrack and crazy clown villains (a movie nightmare that sometimes feels like a fond memory in the MCU-addled landscape of the moment).", "In keeping with the film's likeably juvenile remit, the bombastic CGI clashes are undercut by the combatants' reliably foul mouths, ability to form themselves into giant middle fingers, and their generally sticky physicality, which comes across like a mischievous alien parody of Body Worlds.", "", "
The film's release was pushed back by a year due to COVID-19.(Supplied: Sony)
", "Hardy, who co-wrote the story with returning screenwriter Kelly Marcel, is clearly fond of his knockabout monster, playing up the dissonance between Eddie's nebbish nattering and Venom's bellowing non-sequiturs.", "Venom's dedication to reuniting Eddie with his true love-slash-beard, Anne Weying \u2014\u00a0Michelle Williams, returning with a sporting straight face \u2014\u00a0leads to some of the movie's funniest moments, where otherwise sappy emotional advice takes on a strange poignancy coming from a seven-foot oil-slick with the tenor of a heavy metal vocalist.", "It's actually rich enough terrain to make you wonder whether the film could have been a little smarter \u2014\u00a0until you realise that making Venom \"mean something\"\u00a0would simply ruin whatever scrappy qualities it possesses.", "With all the tiresome world-building, cynical plays at diversity, and generally inflated sense of cultural significance of the superhero genre, sometimes it's a relief to sit back and experience something that's smart enough to play totally dumb.", "Venom: Let There Be Carnage is in cinemas from November 25."]
